I'm amazed by how many companies talk about shifting from "project" to product funding, that can't assemble a basic business case for each team.
Start here...
For each team, write a business case explaining the financial rationale for why the team exists. What should this include?
What are the enduring areas of focus, the ‚Äúlevers,‚Äù that this team has shown a track record of moving (or could spend more time moving if they were a better-defined team)? These levers should be stable and solution-agnostic, not fleeting or project- or work-focused.
How has money in translated to money out? Remember second- and third-order effects, and time. Not every team will ‚Äúcreate value‚Äù in the near term, but you should be able to frame a sensible guess or estimate here. Start from the thought experiment of the team not having done anything. What happened? What was the impact? The delta should get you in the vicinity.
Put on your finance hat. What should the ‚Äúpivot vs. proceed‚Äù tests be for this team in general? Is it even possible to ‚Äúadd money‚Äù to the team? What would happen? Could the team actually absorb more investment?
How much of the team‚Äôs effort over the last year was squarely in line with the team‚Äôs mission and reason for being, versus adjacent, unacknowledged areas of helping?
Now start answering some questions
1. What problem gets materially worse if this team pauses for six months?
2. What measurable outcomes would most clearly justify this team‚Äôs continued funding?
3. Which costs would increase elsewhere in the organization if this team disappeared?
4. What assumptions about demand, risk, or growth does this team carry?
5. What work does this team do that no other team could realistically absorb?

There are two lines of critique against AI coding that miss the bigger picture:
1. Fast delivery will increase AI slop; Products get bloated.

The primary value of designers and PMs using AI to prototype isn't about handing PRs off to engineers. They don't want to be handed off code.
The value is to reduce one of the 3 product risks we are responsible for:
- Value risk: Confirm with customers and stakeholders that what you're building will be valuable before anyone writes a line of code. Does it solve a problem? Does it unlock new use cases? Does it make users ask "when is this going live?"
- Usability: Is how you're thinking about this intuitive to users? Can they find it, understand it, get the task done with little friction? Is it easier than the alternatives?
- Viability: To build a business case it helps if you can *show* and not just tell how a product change moves the needle. How it aligns with GTM or unlock new revenue. By prototyping early you can add substance to purely theoretical arguments.
The outcome is not that the engineering team is served with a full working PR to approve, but that they work with fewer assumptions overall and have more confidence they're not just shipping useless product.
Whether the team can take your PR as a useful artifact or not is an interesting technical, cultural, process problem but mostly besides the point of prototyping.

If you don't manage the length of your AI-assisted content, it erodes trust quickly. It makes people think:
- You haven't read the content yourself, so why should they?
- You haven't really thought about it enough to distill it into strong arguments.
- You are blindly following what LLMs told you, especially if you are also strongly opinionated.

It doesn't matter whether you used an LLM or not. An LLM "tell" is not really a thing anymore. Everyone uses AI.

The rumors were true. Yesterday, OpenAI launched Sora 2, a next gen video + audio model. It makes clips that look shockingly real, with physics that obey Newton instead of Looney Tunes, and audio synced tightly enough to pass a lip-reading test.
But the wild part isn‚Äôt the model, it‚Äôs the wrapper. Sora 2 arrives dressed as a social app with a vertical feed, remix tools, and a ‚Äúcameo‚Äù feature to drop users into scenes. @[OpenAI](https://www.linkedin.com/company/openai/) is auditioning for @[TikTok](https://www.linkedin.com/company/tiktok/)‚Äôs job.
Sure, the tech is very impressive - but it‚Äôs the strategic chess behind the launch that captured my attention:
(1) The Scarcity Play
Sora access is gated by invite codes or prioritized channels (like ChatGPT Pro). The scarcity play is obvious: invite codes = FOMO = viral hype. Silicon Valley has been playing this tune since Gmail.
But here, exclusivity doubles as a throttle on chaos. By slowly onboarding users, OpenAI gets a live A/B test on how people will break, abuse, and subvert the system. Every invite code is basically a fuse on a firework: light it slowly, not all at once, or you blow off your hand. It‚Äôs not just growth hacking, it‚Äôs trust hacking.
(2) The Copyright Play
OpenAI also made the quietly radical decision to treat copyrighted material as fair game by default - unless the rights holder explicitly says no.
Translation: if you own a movie, a character, a song - congratulations, your IP may now appear in someone‚Äôs Sora video unless you tell OpenAI not to. And even then, you might not be able to just say ‚Äúdon‚Äôt use anything I‚Äôve ever made.‚Äù You‚Äôll need to file takedowns for each work, one by one, like bailing water from a sinking ship with a thimble. Forever.
It‚Äôs a legal Hail Mary, a moral shrug, and a strategic masterstroke all rolled into one. The brilliance (or cynicism) is that ‚Äúopt-out‚Äù scales. Opt-in never would. And while courts grind through years of lawsuits, OpenAI normalizes the precedent simply by shipping it. The real beneficiaries? Beverly Hills law firms billing $2,000 an hour.
(3) The Identity Play
OpenAI is explicitly baking consent into likeness use. To appear in Sora, you first upload a verified ‚Äúcameo‚Äù: a one-time video + audio clip that captures your face and voice. Only then can others use your likeness - and only with your permission. You stay a co-owner, can revoke access, and get notified whenever you‚Äôre dropped into a scene.
It‚Äôs a meaningful attempt to center consent in synthetic identity. But it also opens a stranger frontier: identity as asset class.
- Today it‚Äôs your friend putting your face in a video for fun.
- Tomorrow it‚Äôs a talent agency managing a portfolio of ‚Äúdigital cameos‚Äù for actors, influencers, and eventually you.
OpenAI didn‚Äôt just address deepfake abuse. They opened a market for identity futures. Identity is no longer just protected. It‚Äôs packaged, priced, and platformized. You, too, can rent your face for $99/month. Please read the terms of service.

First of all....Spotify revenues double roughly every five years. They don't 5X. See the chart below. So the question is stupid on it's face.
Second, whatever "logical" arguments the candidate makes are based on zero analysis and zero understanding of the realities, complexities and challenges Spotify (or any other company) is facing.
Third, there is so much subjectivity and bias built into how ANY response ANY candidate gives would be evaluated, that the "discussion" that ensues with the candidate is more likely to harm them than help.
e.g. if the candidate doesn't know much about Spotify or is the kind of person who actually wants to have data and understanding about a topic before answering - i.e. the kind of candidate you probably want on your team - they'll often perform terribly in this situation.
And whether it is Spotify or some other company (Apple, Tesla, Facebook, Dyson etc), it doesn't matter.

So let's stop asking these kinds of questions, and be more thoughtful and diligent in our hiring processes. Let's use questions that actually assess important attributes of the candidates we interview. We owe them that much. And it will only benefit ourselves as Product Leaders and our companies.

I love my product brief templates but there's a fatal flaw: creating briefs only when you have a solution in mind.
Typically, briefs are split into a problem/opportunity section and a solution section. So far so good. üí™
Until it turns out you only create product briefs when you are set on a specific solution.
This can lead to a few problems:
‚Äì You waste time back-filling the brief with the problem section. Unless the problem space can challenge that one specific solution, why waste everyone's time?
‚Äì If you're lucky, the team will question your problem space. But if you're set on a solution this will be an awkward discussion.
‚Äì You hurt the trust between Product and other functions when your brief becomes fluff. You may not see it, but it will happen.
You can see this when the Jobs To Be Done is just a rephrased user story. When the Data / Insights section is consistently empty or contains fluff such as "we have observed that [...]". Or when people simply remove entire sections from the brief. ‚ú®
In my experience this can easily happen when there's a disconnect between an aspirational state of the product culture and where it really is in practice. The brief is where you want to be, but it's not enough to get there.
I don't have a tested solution here but some thoughts:
‚Äì Create briefs before you have a solution. This is tough to impossible depending on the setting since problem statements often circulate in the hallways. No one says "that's a great problem, let's collect all we know about it in one place". It floats around until some people agree on solutions, and then it goes into the brief. (Lack of UXRs anyone?)
‚Äì Split the briefs into two separate documents: "Problem/Opportunity Brief" and "Solution Brief". Might be perceived as "too much process" depending on the context.
‚Äì Take an unbiased look into your discovery process. Do you just take one or two comments from support to prioritise a feature? Is your team empowered to participate in some way, or do they just wait for tickets? A formal brief in an informal setting won't be enough to nudge the culture in the direction you want.
‚Äì Be OK with some solutions not needing a lot of discovery. Don't back-fill with fluff, just explain as it is. If the opportunity is to build a team invitation system, a common table-stakes B2B feature, perhaps it doesn't need as much discovery as "Use GenAI to make our customers 20x efficient".
Have you seen or contributed to fluffy product briefs too? Designers and Engineers, looking at you. Do you feel that the problem space is just theatre play to satisfy a template or make the PM feel smart? Been there, done that. üò¨

What often freaks engineers out is the idea of time allotment. This is where at the start of the quarter I take our planned initiatives and allocate certain amount of time for each.
"How can you estimate the time we need to build this if even we don't know!?"
It's not a time estimate though. It's a time investment.
Every quarter you get around 12 weeks to invest into different bets. A problem with just going at it one at a time is that you lose a sense of time and can easily overspend on an initiative, pushing other ones out of the quarter. This creates a mess for the following quarter, and damages morale.
I learned this way back in art classes. Your paper is the space you operate in (a quarter in our case).
If you start drawing a sitting person by
detailing the nose,
then the eye,
then the neck,
and the body,
by the time you get to the leg you'll realise it won't fit.
And you kinda wanted the leg too.
That's why you sketch it first in broad strokes ‚Äì you allocate roughly where things should go and how much space they need.
I hadn't really seen this before and thought I was improvising a process too much, but then I found it's also at the core of Shape Up by Ryan Singer, and has a better name: appetite.
"When shaping, we focus less on estimates and more on our appetite. Instead of asking how much time it will take to do some work, we ask: How much time do we want to spend? How much is this idea worth?"
https://lnkd.in/dgrQxUE7
A drawback is that it is top-down: you define a solution, shape it up in broad strokes and hand off to the team. The team can still figure out the details but they don't choose the opportunities themselves. This may or may not align with your goals, but if you have a set of bets, it's a good way to sketch your way through a quarter and not lose a leg.

Documentation is how LLMs learn in the first place. What's changing now isn't that documentation itself is becoming obsolete. It's only going to be used by LLMs as well as people.
All in all, it should be a net gain, not loss:
‚Äì LLMs can generate documentation for us, or assist in the process. The dreaded writing process will become more of an instruction-review-feedback loop with an LLM. This can be great if it results in more/better documentation written overall.
‚Äì The final documentation will live on, but how we measure success (page visits, "X people found this helpful") will need to adapt. Perhaps there will be ways to test the quality differently ‚Äì either checklists (like "has version-specific documentation") or some version of accessibility tests which would help LLMs understand information more accurately (e.g. comparison tables use either text values or images/SVG with aria values, and not plan images) or a more advanced test, like making sure information is structured well enough for embeddings to be effective.
‚Äì The layer between the documentation and someone's specific problem will largely get replaced by an LLM. Not great for StackOverflow but pretty cool for engineers. So it's more about the middleman than the documentation itself.
As an example, I PoC'd a Zapier app recently for the first time, never before reading Zapier's docs and never using our own product's GraphQL API or even writing a line of GraphQL before.
That internal GraphQL API documentation was the absolute enabler for the fast PoC. I still had to consult both documentations and of course use my own logic, but the approach made me at least 3x efficient, due to my non-existent previous experience with either ends of the integration.
I say the documentation is here to stay, but many things will change. How we write it, how we access it, how we measure it.

Do you still start with "Welcome to [Product Name]" in your onboarding? You might reconsider.
These phrases can feel like filler text, almost saying, "I wasn't really sure what to put here."
It's weak because users typically have several questions in mind when they begin.
Hitting them with "Welcome to [MY_PRODUCT]" or "Hello, [FIRST_NAME]"? That's a direct path to banner blindness.
Being welcomed is more about feeling than being told. You can say it, but it doesn‚Äôt guarantee the user will FEEL it.
Instead, they might feel:
‚Äì Lost. "Where am I? Is this right?"
‚Äì Confused. "What's in it for me?"
‚Äì Annoyed. "This isn't what I was looking for."
True welcoming comes from job alignment and clear progress.
* Alignment *
The product must resonate with the user's specific needs and the job they intend to complete. Alignment gap almost always exists, but can be thoughtfully minimised.
A disjointed onboarding experience widens this gap. Poorly designed products often completely miss the user's expectations.
* Progress to the desired outcome *
In the Jobs to Be Done (JTBD) theory, users ‚Äúhire‚Äù products to achieve progress towards their desired outcome. If they can't see how hiring your product progresses them further, the big ‚ÄúWelcome, Bob!‚Äù won‚Äôt do much.
It's like mistakenly crashing a party. They might drunkenly exclaim ‚ÄúWelcome to the partey!‚Äù but you know you need to get out asap.
A clear progression path could be as basic as a descriptive headline or a CTA that says ‚ÄúCustomize Report‚Äù over a vague ‚ÄúNext‚Äù.
So, next time you're tempted to slap a "Welcome" on the screen, pause.
List out 3 things that would make users FEEL it, so they know they‚Äôre at the right party.
Then craft the message around one of these.
(And if you hit a snag, ping me.)

I bootstrapped 3 startups in 13 years. These are the 8 biggest misconceptions I always hear about bootstrappers: üßê
1. We raise $0 external capital.
Unless founders can avoid hiring, cover startup costs, and sustain themselves till they get to revenue, it‚Äôs likely that they‚Äôll need some initial capital. Bootstrapping refers to "no institutional capital". Most founders invest their own money and raise from family and friends to get started.
2. We don't want to give away equity.
It took 2.5 hard years in my last startup to make our first $10. A friend said to me, "It‚Äôs okay to raise a bit so you can be comfortable.‚Äù thinking I didn‚Äôt raise because I wanted to keep all the equity. Reality was, I had complete freedom and didn't want to lose it.
3. We're less ambitious.
"If you don't shoot for unicorn status, you're not ambitious enough." is a fallacy fueled by VCs because it's good for their business. Starting a company is in itself ambition. We know success is self-defined, we don't need anyone else to agree.
4. We're unable to raise capital.
VC-backed startups must fuel growth at all costs, which forces them into a vicious cycle of constantly raising more. We don't subscribe to that way of life. At least not yet until we know that's what we want. Many bootstrappers raise much later when they can demand favorable terms.
5. We're cheap.
We're cost conscious and optimize for getting the most return on investment. That's not the same as cheap, which means paying the least. We're profit driven, so we can't afford to compromise on time and quality of work. We pay what is needed to get to revenue fastest.
6. We don't make money for a while.
We make money, just not yet on the startup we're bootstrapping. We do whatever it takes to fund our companies. We work on them on the side, take consulting gigs, or agency work.
7. We have smaller exits.
We can sell whenever we want but VC-backed startups can't without board approval and often come with liquidation preferences. Selling a bootstrapped startup at $10m where founders own 90% = $9m. To do better, VC-backed founders need 10% of a $100m exit which is often not big enough for VCs.
8. We struggle more.
It's true that comparatively we struggle more in the initial years. But our struggle ends the day we hit profitability. We don't need to grow at an unrealistic pace to satisfy investors until we sell or die. Profitability gives us the freedom to live and work how we want. üçæ
Many people think bootstrapping is a financial decision when it's often a lifestyle choice.
Raising VC, however, is usually a financial decision without consideration for the lifestyle that comes with it.
There isn‚Äôt a right or wrong way to build a business. But there's a right way FOR YOU.
The question founders should be asking before choosing which path to take is not, "How much money do I want to make from this?"
But rather, "What kind of life do I want to live while building this for the next 10 years?"

CALM IS IN THE BLACK
From the very first month we started the business back in 1999, we were profitable. We‚Äôve remained profitable every year since then.
We‚Äôve absolutely had our share of good fortune and luck, but we‚Äôve also intentionally never gotten ahead of ourselves. We‚Äôve always kept our costs in check and never made a move that would push us back from black to red.
Why? Because crazy‚Äôs in the red. Calm‚Äôs in the black.
Until you‚Äôre running a profitable business, you‚Äôre always almost out of business. You‚Äôre racing the runway. Fretting about whether you‚Äôll take off in time. Worrying about how to make payroll at the last moment if you don‚Äôt. Talk about a pressurized environment!
When companies are in the red, employees worry about their jobs. People aren‚Äôt stupid‚Äîthey know that burning cash means the good times won‚Äôt last. The possibility of layoffs are always nagging. CVs are always at the ready. And as market sentiments change, valuations shift, and money becomes more expensive, being in the red leads to even more danger ahead.
Revenue alone is no defense either because revenue without a profit margin isn‚Äôt going to save you. You can easily go broke generating revenue‚Äîmany companies have. But you can‚Äôt go broke generating a profit.
Profit means time to think, space to explore. It means being in control of your own destiny and schedule.
Without profit, something is always on fire. When companies talk about burn rates, two things are burning: money and people. One you‚Äôre burning up, one you‚Äôre burning out.
